posts.text: Cooking / Recipes / Video On The Go Vegan Lunch Ideas for School Or Work (Bento Box) Caitlin Shoemaker has created 3 super easy and yummy vegan lunch ideas that are perfect for taking to work or school! Meal 1 is a soba noodle salad and brownies. Meal 2 is a curry chickpea wrap. Meal 3 is sushi burrito and pb&j energy bites. Caitlin shows how all 3 meals can be conveniently packed to take on the go — she used bento boxes, but any container will do! Make as much or as little as you want – these recipes are here to inspire you and get you out of the “same thing every day” rut! So check out the video below to see the recipes in action: Read the full recipes in the video description here . Comment via Facebook

Vegetarian Heaven on Earth - Edit Posted by Drumila Dasa on 06 Jan 2015. If you have not visited The Good Karma Cafe yet, please go, but with a warning: It very well may soon become your favorite hang out and eatery! What's not to like? Exotic, roomy ambiance with subtle soothing mantra music. An awesome juice and smoothie bar. And an array of wholesome tasty dishes. Whole meals with rice and salads, wraps and sandwiches. Hearty 'soup of the day' and scrumptious desserts. New Orleans has been longing for a pure vegetarian experience, and I am here to testify that 'The Good Karma Cafe' has fully filled the need! Updated from previous review on Monday January 05, 2015 
Pros: Spiritually uplifting and peaceful, Healthy choice eatery, Wonderful friendly staff

thread.title: Life Alive Urban Oasis and Organic Cafe - Cambridge Massachusetts Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Life Alive Urban Oasis and Organic Cafe - Cambridge Massachusetts Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Life Alive Urban Oasis and Organic Cafe - Cambridge Massachusetts Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
A very welcome addition to Central Square - Edit Posted by VeganVagabond on 12 Jul 2011. I eat here all the time, so I figure it's about time to write a review. In all honesty, I hesitate to do this because the place is already getting very popular (crowded) and I'm afraid I have nothing but nice things to say. Nearly all the menu is vegan, so there is a wide range of choices. Most of the warm meals consist of a grain (usually brown rice or quinoa), a wide variety of fresh organic vegetables, some nuts or seeds, and some sort of sauce. You can get these either in a bowl or as a wrap, but I always get a bowl because you can fit more veggies in it (and they do!). I originally wasn't too keen on some of these warm dishes because the put more sauce on it then I would like (many won't mind this, but I prefer my food as unadulterated as possible -- let the veggies speak for themselves). Then I found that they were more than happy to go light on the sauce, or omit it entirely. The staff are very friendly and will do anything they can to help you make the most of your meal. My current favorite is "The Innocent", but I am also quite find of "The Fool" and "The Lover". They also have several meal-size salads, most of which come with one of two varieties of hummus: lemon-garlic or red-lentil. I highly recommend the red-lentil, it is low-fat, protein-rich, and very tasty. On the days that I get a salad, I generally alternate between "The Explorer" and "The Sufi Poet". There are also soups of the day, some of which are truly awesome (I love the black bean) so definitely take a look at these before you order. A cup of soup and one of their big salads makes a perfect meal. There are also "warm cheesy wraps" on the menu, but they aren't vegan (and even if they were I wouldn't be likely to order them, I'm not a big fan of vegan cheese), so I won't say anything about them. And they have an amazing juice bar which I keep meaning to try, but I haven't yet. The atmosphere is awesome -- full of plants and funky artwork. It has a great vibe and is a really cool place to just hang out. Unfortunately this (and the great food) have made it very popular and it can get crowded. I recommend avoiding the lunch hour rush -- go before noon or after 1:30. The only thing that would make Life Alive a more perfect place than it already is would be some homemade whole wheat bread (currently they don't offer bread of any sort, only the whole wheat tortillas they use for the wraps). 
Pros: Great food, Great staff, Great atmosphere 
Cons: Can be crowded, No bread

organizations.name: organic cafe - cambridge massachusetts vegetarian restaurant

Vegan options - Edit Posted by lesterville on 22 Nov 2016. Went here for lunch after finding on Happy Cow. On that particular Saturday, they were making changes to the menu and only had two vegan offerings. I went with the buffalo cauliflower (this is an appetizer portion and fortunately, I was not super hungry) and it was excellent. I've made this at home and this was better than mine. The hot sauce was tangy and the vegan ranch was tasty too. Some celery sticks would have been a welcome addition. The server was very friendly and told me the owner is vegan. He forgot to bring my beer so I got it for free. They were having a vegan brunch the next day which I was sad to miss. I recommend calling to see what vegan offerings they have that day. The menu on their website looks to not have been updated for a while. Updated from previous review on 2016-11-22 
Pros: Owner is vegan

thread.title: Feed The Earthlings - Gold Coast Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Feed The Earthlings - Gold Coast Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Feed The Earthlings - Gold Coast Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Earthlings are into fast food ;) - Edit Posted by Rico on 16 Apr 2016. FTE is a small shop off a connecting road through Ashmore, which is easy to miss as you drive by - as my friend and i did on our first pass. They're situated to the side of the road, down a bank, so there's a good chance you'd never find them if not for a huge, hand painted vegan sign at the front of the shop. My friend spotted that as we went past, so we turned around and got it second time. We had three things off their non-pizza menu: 'fish' and chips, 'chicken' burger and onion rings. The 'fish' were tofu slices with a fish-like flavouring and had a really nice, crispy batter. The chips were also nice. My friend was a little alarmed by the 'chicken' burger, since she said it had the taste ad texture of the real thing, but she reconciled herself to that and enjoyed it. She also had the onion rings, which she was almost ecstatic about (she's an onion ring fan). I tried one, and it had a super crispy batter. The person who served us was chatty and friendly - full marks for service. There was a slow stream of people that turned up while we were there, so despite this place's obscure location, people are aware and willing to show up for the semi-industrial takeaway experience. 
Pros: top notch fast food, friendly service, reasonable prices 
Cons: very limited table seating, might be tricky to find, semi-industrial location

thread.title: Pan Comido Vegetariano - Tonala - Mexico City Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Pan Comido Vegetariano - Tonala - Mexico City Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Pan Comido Vegetariano - Tonala - Mexico City Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
A Gem In Mexico City :) - Edit Posted by kezia on 24 Nov 2013. As a vegan traveling to Mexico for the first time I was very skeptical about how well I would eat. On my first day we came across this gem in the heart of the city. and all I can say is I ate VERY well for the rest of my trip! Pom Comido is very modern and quirky, with interesting touches, Ike serving drinks in jam jars and beautifully hand written menus. Everything is vegetarian but almost all dishes can be adapted to vegan if requested. The first meal I tried was the veggie burger. Being a vegan and not eating cheese, the cheese in my burger was replaced with Tofu, which worked really well. It was served in a nice basket with crisps on the side. I also tried the "Burritos" I had mine with black beans and mushrooms with Tofu. again it was delicious! As for deserts I really wasn't expecting to be able to order one at all, but to my suprise there was at least 3- 4 vegan options. I had the vegan chocolate cookie. Here in the U.K. I actually bake professionally as a vegan, and I honestly could not have made this cookie better myself. It was amazing! The staff were nice and keen to help, despite some of them having limited English. They were very accommodating too. As I arrived in Mexico City from Cancun where everyone accepts dollars. I naively thought that this was the same for the whole of Mexico, but to my suprise. No. The owner manager? was very kind to exchange my $50 note for Pesos on the condition we changed it back with her the following day. This was very trusting of her and showed very good customer service. All I can say is that any Vegan or Veggie traveling to Mexico City much try Pan Comido. 
Pros: Almost every dish can be made vegan, It's in a great central location, Food is delicious 
Cons: No food marked as "vegan" , A lot of cheese is used

thread.title: Mango Vegan Street Food - Bracka - Warsaw Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Mango Vegan Street Food - Bracka - Warsaw Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Mango Vegan Street Food - Bracka - Warsaw Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Good food. Unfriendly staff. - Edit Posted by TofuCelt on 17 Dec 2016. We were pleasantly surprised to see how good Poland was for vegan food. Unfortunately the friendliness of staff does not reflect the choice. Everywhere we went in Poland, we were met with the most unfriendly staff we've ever come across. Don't expect warm welcomes. This place, however, is slightly more friendly than the Mango Vegan on Zlota Street. This place was also bigger with more room for eating in, than the one on Zlota Street. This is definitely the better of the two Mango Vegan's that we ate in. However, it is more difficult to find it, but be patient. Although the food is the same in both places, this one is definitely a better place to eat in at. We never got to try the third place which, ironically, was nearer to where we stayed. Like Mango Vegan on Zlota Street, there is a decent selection on the menu. As we all preferred the Komoso 'cheese' burger the most on our visit to the Mango Vegan on Zlota Street, we all went for that again here. The burger itself is of average size, but the bun is well filled with extras - lettuce, onion, tomato, sauces, etc. It takes a big mouth to get your fangs around this bun burger. It is quite filling and the taste is nice. We also had a plate of four falafels on a plate of salad. Not the best, or worst, I've ever had, but they were a good size. Bigger than normal with a slightly above average taste. For a drink, we had a Hemp and Green smoothie. Both tasted nice but had a strange consistency to it. They didn't seem 'smoothed out' enough. Slightly below average I'd say. But at least they seemed very healthy. The cost was a fair price and the service quick. All in all, a good place to eat without having to worry if something is vegan or not. Unfortunately, it is almost all ruined by the lack of friendliness of staff. Updated from previous review on 2016-12-17 
Pros: Good choice, Fair price, Fairly central 
Cons: Unfriendly staff, Difficult to find, Could be cleaner

organizations.name: mango vegan street food - bracka - warsaw vegan restaurant

thread.title: Dark Arts Coffee Academy - Coffs Harbour Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Dark Arts Coffee Academy - Coffs Harbour Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Dark Arts Coffee Academy - Coffs Harbour Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Mum Went Hungry - Edit Posted by happytummiesbrisbane on 08 Oct 2017. I had such high hopes for this place. Inspired interior, unique aesthetic, and enticing vegan/gf options. I was so incredibly let down. Earlier in the day, a vegan friend of mine ordered a soy latte and was made sick by the dairy milk and heapings of sugar added to his order. Later that evening, excited by a generous and exciting selection of vegan and gluten free options, we decided to head there for dinner. The waiting staff were attentive. My mother ordered the "chef's special" seafood, which (and perhaps I didn't get the joke), was all imported canned fish. When the first of our 5 meals arrived, hard plastic was found in the pizza, and we received an apology and offer of a free drink. When the second lot of meals arrived, the first were well tucked into already. The pizza we received was presumed vegan when ordering as the menu description listed only vegan ingredients, and did not specify that it was a cheese-topped pizza. I passed it onto another attendee. We received the wrong salad (a vegan one was ordered and we received chorizo), and I had to bring this to the main counter to have amended. We were still waiting for my mother's order as the other meals were finished, so I decided to cancel it. Upon advising this, I learned her order hadn't been recorded at all. One of the staff offered to prepare her canned sardine meal for her then (all other meals were finished), on the house, and feeling embarrassed and put on the spot she quietly smiled an agreement. She didn't understand her order hadn't been taken in the first place, and thought it was just being served now. I approached the counter a second time to cancel it. Otherwise, the wait staff were conspicuously avoiding us at this point. We still paid the full price of nearly $90 for the experience and my mother, the most excited for the meal, left hungry. I would like to make a special mention however, of the bartender with the long hair donning the Led Zeppelin shirt, who listened attentively, and goodnaturedly acknowledged my disheartedness on both occasions I explained the situation. 
Pros: Vibrant aesthetic / themed decor, Live music, Gluten free options 
Cons: Disorganised staff, Disjointed food delivery, Lack of concern for attendee expense & experience

thread.title: Whole Foods Market - Sedona Arizona Health-food-store Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Whole Foods Market - Sedona Arizona Health-food-store Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Whole Foods Market - Sedona Arizona Health-food-store Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Thank you for existing, Whole Foods - Edit Posted by jenly on 18 Apr 2017. I thought Sedona, being the land of vortexes and crystals, would have a plethora of veg dining options but I turned out to be mistaken. Enter the Whole Foods Market, which I believe took over a storefront called Natural Frontiers a few years ago. As noted in other reviews, Whole Foods does not have the best deli and salad bar selections, certainly nothing like what I am used to seeing at my local WFM. However, they do have an acceptable number of veg offerings and my kids enjoyed roaming through the cold and hot food bars and filling little containers. We visited the freezer section and stocked up on frozen entrees, and we bought groceries to prepare some of our own dinners, plus sandwiches and snacks for hikes. The produce section was a little disappointing but still adequate. We were on vacation and I really did NOT want to cook, but the dining options in Sedona were so limited we wound up visiting the WFM about four times in our five days there. My advice for anyone travelling through Sedona would be to get a room with a kitchen--even something with just a microwave--and keep this Whole Foods in mind. I actually got the idea to visit Sedona with my family because a cashier in my local WFM told me she had worked in the WFM in Sedona. So even though it is the lmost underwhelming WFM I have been in, if it had not existed our vacation would have been appreciably more miserable. And because I feel so grateful, I am awarding it four stars. 
Pros: selection of vegan grocery items, granola/hiking snack bar, late hours 
Cons: produce section decent but could be better, deli/buffet could be better, expensive whole foods prices

Great food, meh service. - Edit Posted by hailseitan23 on 29 Sep 2016. I went here for lunch and dinner, and it is amazing. The Philly Cheese Steak is one of the best vegan sandwiches I've ever had, and the Betterfinger and Betterfinger milkshake are amazing desserts. The service is very quick and the meals are made fresh. The environment and employees leave much to be desired though. The employees are abrupt (even by New York standards) and one time, I found them closing up 20 minutes early and refusal to serve any customers. It is an extremely tiny room that is very hot and cramped with not much seating, so it's much better to take it to-go than trying to eat there. I would go back in the future, but I will definitely get it to go and eat in a much more comfortable (and cool) environment. 
Pros: The milkshakes are amazing 
Cons: Staff closes up early

thread.title: Vegan In Bangladesh - The Veggie Blog
thread.title_full: Vegan In Bangladesh - The Veggie Blog

posts.author: Marie Neren
posts.title: Vegan In Bangladesh - The Veggie Blog
posts.text:
General Vegan In Bangladesh Unfortunately, there is no magic word in Bangladesh to easily describe your dietary preferences. It is very difficult for a Bangladeshi person to understand that you do not want any meat. At least, this was my experience while trying to eat vegan food in Bangladesh. In Bangladesh, everything vegetarian will most likely be vegan too. They never use Ghee, since vegetable oil is way cheaper. This is especially true for street food–places will use mustard or corn oil. The kitchen of Bangladesh is very Indian-inspired. But where India is the master of vegetarian food, Bangladesh has a whole other (meat) culture. One important thing to keep in mind is that there will always be traces of meat in your food. Meat will typically be fried in the same oil as veggie dishes, or your vegan food will be served with the same spoon used for meat dishes. Because of this, I had a bone or two mixed into my vegan dishes. Yuk. The few times this happened, I gave away my food to a person on the street in need. Singharas and samosas are mostly vegan, but don’t trust the ones filled with onions! Sometimes I would repeat 15 times: “NO MEAT!” and still find meat in my dish. People will lie to sell, but many times they just do not understand “no meat.” Luckily during my time in Bangladesh, I had brought some green tea leaves from Myanmar with me so I could add some greens to my rice dishes. This way I at least got my greens in and was able to spice my dishes up with a small selection of spices and Sriracha (which I always carry with me). It’s not a fine dining experience, but sometimes you just have to make do. Myamarian green tea leaves with rice and Sriracha Tour Group BD made my vegan Bangladeshi food experience much easier. They truly understood what ‘vegan’ means, so on the boat tour to the Sundarbans, I was spoiled like no other. The chef made me a separate delicious dish every day. Moreover, I could always count on these guys to help me out with anything. 
Vegan dish on the Sundarban Tour 
The kitchen on the boat to Sundarbans Govindas (Hindu restaurants) can be found all around the country. In Sree Mangal I tried about four dishes for 750 Taka (+/- 8 Euro). Vegan food in Sree Magal Govindas The people of Bangladesh are very hospitable. They’ll take you in and feed you without any questions. I’ve enjoyed several beautiful vegan meals made with love and only in traditional ways. I have never seen as many small dishes packed with flavor as I have in Shylet–fried eggplant and zucchini, soy no-meat balls, mashed potato with onion, fresh salad, dahl (lentils), ..etc. A true feast compared to the bland rice I was eating most of the other time. Home cooked vegan meal in Shylet At one point during my travels, I met the wonderful guides of Tour Group BD in Cox Bazar and went on a camping adventure to Sonadia Island. While there, I enjoyed simple yet delicious meals cooked on improvised wooden fires. While there, I lived off of rice with potato and an occasional tomato or two. Once again, I spiced it up with Sriracha, since means were very scarce on the deserted island. Wood fire cooked meal on Sonadia Island Back in Dhaka, I really felt like spoiling myself with something other than fried food and potatoes. I took the hike to the restaurant Shadhu Bhojon in Dhaka, which I found through HappyCow . The food was pricey compared to elsewhere, but it satisfied my western craving for sure! Rice with greens at Shadhu Bhojon And of course, I wouldn’t be a Belgian if I wasn’t craving chocolate at least once a day. It had been such a long time since I had tasted any cacao delight, so I mixed up some coconut oil with cacao powder and coated some pomegranate with it. Chocolate with pomegranate Long story short: Bangladesh is by no means a vegan heaven, so keep this in mind if you want to travel to this hidden gem and maintain a vegan diet. Understand that this is a poor country where dietary choices are foreign or strictly religious. Here are some final tips for vegan travel in Bangladesh: book tours with Tour Group BD and avoid eating street food, unless it’s fresh fruits and veggies of course. On the streets, go raw! And when in someone’s home, kindly explain you don’t eat animal products and you’ll surely get spoiled beyond your expectations. 

About the author: I am Marie, a simple farmer’s daughter without a plan. In October 2015 I decided to leave everything behind, sell my furniture and reduce my belongings so they could fit in a backpack. I’m determined to realize my dreams and travel the world. You can follow my blog at www.belgianturtle.com and find me on Facebook: www.facebook.com/belgianturtle . Comment via Facebook

thread.title: Mona's Cafe and Deli - New Orleans Louisiana Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Mona's Cafe and Deli - New Orleans Louisiana Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Mona's Cafe and Deli - New Orleans Louisiana Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
serendipity - Edit Posted by gratia_plena on 05 May 2007. i caught mona's from the corner of my eye; thrilled to read that they served mediterranean cuisine (which usually means there's something veggie/interesting that i can eat), we magically found parking like two blocks away and ran to the place. it's a strangely casual cross between a very reasonably priced middle-eastern grocery, hookah shop, and restaurant. i recall that they had a decent selection of entrees, but being pressed for time, we ordered a sampler that i think consisted of falafel, hummus, baba ganoush, cous cous, tabouli, and of course, pita. the only thing was that for what it was, the plate was a tad expensive (like $9.00 for some dip and 3 pieces of falafel! i think the rest of the food was more reasonably priced, tho)... but it was soooo good! even my carnivore bf was pleased. we also shared a cup of their turkish coffee, and tho it was as thick & black as tar, it was good and... sobering? haha ooh! and their lebanese tea with pine nuts is absolutely delectable. i've been dying for it since i returned home to tx. (i can't wait to move to NOLA this fall! hehe) it was a nice surprise to stop somewhere half from desperation, half out of curiosity and find that not only did it have stuff that i could eat/buy (sadly, veggie places are scarce in NOLA), but that i would gladly return to! YaY, mona's! 
Pros: fresh, delish food!, good selection!!, funky grocery!!! 
Cons: slow-ish service, portions could be better, they seemed short-staffed

thread.title: Peacefood Cafe - Downtown - New York City New York Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Peacefood Cafe - Downtown - New York City New York Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Peacefood Cafe - Downtown - New York City New York Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Too many choices! - Edit Posted by void on 17 Aug 2016. Pfc definitely offers too many options, I've always struggled with choosing what to eat (which means I will have to go there again so many times!). The place itself looks nice, though I found it unbearably loud while sitting in the middle of the room and only slightly better when sitting next to a wall on my next visit. This is something they definitely need to work on. It feels like a bar or a fast-food joint, not a nice restaurant. On the other hand, all of their food as nothing but impressed me. Let me list what I had the pleasure of enjoying: * Pfc seitan foccacia: loved everything about it: the bread, the "cheese", the seitan, pesto,... It was just about twice as much as I could eat. Though no big deal, as they will happily wrap up the rest to go. This was a great meal the day after as well. * Cheeseburger on foccacia: my boyfriend had it, I tried a bit, it was very tasty. Great patty too - he said if nobody had told him it's vegan, he wouldn't have taken it for meat. The foccacia is a nice twist on the usual burger buns, and the onion rings add some great texture. * Macho nachos: are advertised as an appetizer, but I just made them my entree :) I was quite impressed, they appear to fry their own tortilla chips. Great toppings; maybe there could have been more guacamole, but I love that stuff, so I might not be the average customer. * Fresh gingerade: if you love ginger (like me), you'll love this. * Strawberry cheesecake: a true New York cheesecake. Vegan. Tasty. And a h ge slice. * Mini brownies: some of the best brownies I've had. * Macaroon: alright, nothing I'd order again. Price-wise, it's not cheap, but I can't complain. 
Pros: extremely tasty food, huge selection, great desserts that you can look at before choosin 
Cons: noisy atmosphere

locations.name: new york city new york vegan restaurant

Cooking / Recipes / Video 3 Easy Vegan Microwave Meals (Dorm Room Friendly) 
We’re really excited about this recipe video from Caitlin Shoemaker because it’s so practical and budget-friendly! Caitlin shares 3 creative vegan dishes that can be made super fast in a microwave, which is perfect for college kids in dorms (or for any time you’re just not in the mood to use the oven)! These recipes are all different but use the same ingredients, which makes it easier and cheaper to buy what you need. In this video you will learn how to make sweet potato chickpea boats, a spinach and veggie salad, and sweet potato “toasts”. But best of all, you will be reminded of just how easy, cheap, and delicious vegan food can be!

posts.title: The Vine Cafe and Market - St Louis Missouri Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
The Vine Cafe and Market Veg-options 3171 S Grand Blvd , St Louis , Missouri , USA , 63118 Serves meat, vegan options available. Small Lebanese grocery store with an attached restaurant where you could get a falafel sandwich, tabbouleh, and other veg-suitable salads, labeled. Categories: Mediterranean, Take-out, Middle Eastern, Lebanese, Non-veg I love the vine! - Edit Posted by CatSchleicher on 13 Oct 2017. The Vine is my go-to restaurant when I’m eating out! Its perfect for groups with non-veg folks. I share the appetizer combo and an extra order if falafel with my s/o and its amazing! 
Pros: Extremely affordable , Vegan options, Environment By submitting this post you agree to HappyCow Terms Post Your Response Yummy, cheap, awesome. - Edit Posted by LuluLovin on 05 Oct 2016. Me and my date first went into this other restaurant next door (treehouse) and I just wasn't feelin' it at that place, on top of it being pretty expensive. So when we left I saw hookah and falafel on the sign for this place so I was sold. Pretty sure I had the baked eggplant and it was AHmazing, my date loved his choice of food too (both vegan options). I had to pack mine up because it was such a big portion! It was a perfect sunny day so we had hookah with our food, which gave a fun ambiance. We had no issues other than not getting the correct hookah flavor and it being kinda nasty (tasted unclean), but thats not a food complaint so it's kinda irrelevant for the majority but keep in mind when getting that option. There were lots of families this day and they were pretty busy and we still got served promptly and kindly, no complaints! There were more vegan options here than compared to other places and I'll definitely be coming back here again soon. 
Pros: Yummm, Cheap , Great Ambience 
Cons: None with food and service!, Hookah was Bleh By submitting this post you agree to HappyCow Terms Post Your Response Great family place - Edit Posted by mg66 on 17 Apr 2016. This is a great family place, and you'll see many middle eastern families eating here. The reason it's great for my family is the price - we can have falafel night for $20! You just can't beat that for a family of four. The food is very good and the staff is cheerful. What more could we want? For the record, i tried to give 5 stars, but Happy Cow limits non-vegetarian restaurants to 4 stars max. OK, I understand. 
Pros: affordable, falafel is always a good thing, friendly staff By submitting this post you agree to HappyCow Terms Post Your Response falafel! - Edit Posted by MeM on 18 Mar 2016. Take out orders regularly missing essentials, like sauce, or all the food, or sides, or extras you paid for. Dont bother. Better places on South Grand. Their falafel dinner is good. Decent portion size (although the falafel dinner went from 10pc to 9pc) everything I've had there is good: Fries, lentil soup, hummus, sandwiches. Never really impressed with the staff and I always double check my order, I've had to drive back for missing pita. I'd like to blame it on the fact that they're always doing brisk business...but I don't think that's it. I've been ignored, treated curtly, and i went around and around with a staff that said i should have a yogurt salad, in response to me looking for a vegan substitute for the soup they were out of. Updated from previous review on Saturday January 24, 2015 Updated from previous review on Friday March 18, 2016 
Cons: indifferent staff, Orders regularly missing essentials By submitting this post you agree to HappyCow Terms Post Your Response Wow wow wow! - Edit Posted by Redheaded Vegan on 21 Nov 2013. Yes, three wows! I'm stopped in St. Louis this evening on my way across the country and a friend took me to dinner here. On the drive over he mentioned how much he loves the food and that he's never had anything here he hasn't loved. He's omni, so I wasn't sure if the same would prove true for me. Oh boy, did it ever! We both started with the lentil soup and it was a flavor explosion in my mouth. So perfectly balanced and complex it made me wish my lentil soups were even half as good. He got a pot of coffee with cardamon and was so excited by the flavor, I had to try, despite the fact that I don't really do caffeine. It was served in a beautiful pot with two dainty cups and it only took a small sip to realize what he was in love with. It was thick, strong, and flavorful. If I was a regular coffee lover, I would have ordered one for myself. I wasn't so sure about my dinner choices. The menu is very clearly marked with vegan selections and I wasn't super-excited by the basic descriptions. With our server's hearty recommendation of the mixed vegetable plate, I ordered that and was more than pleasantly surprised. It was so incredibly delicious and beautifully presented. It was a combination of cauliflower, zucchini, eggplant, and peppers over a wonderfully spiced rice served with some pickled vegetables. My only caution is that it was served with a tahini sauce which appeared too light in color to be vegan. I asked the server and she immediately apologized, saying that there is yogurt in it. The meal was incredibly delicious without it. We also split grape leaves which were perfectly done and had a pot of mint tea after dinner. The service was excellent - attentive and friendly and we felt extremely welcome. If I lived in St. Louis this would definitely be a place I frequented often! Updated from previous review on Wednesday November 20, 2013 Updated from previous review on Wednesday November 20, 2013 
Pros: Delicious food, Clearly marked vegan options, Friendly service 
Cons: Served dairy with vegan meal

The term "fast food" is not a positive term in English, too much bad association with poisonous corporate burgers, sweeteners and flavourings. thread.title: The Green Kitchen - St Albans Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: The Green Kitchen - St Albans Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: The Green Kitchen - St Albans Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Great place to get a vegan breakfast - Edit Posted by dropscone on 12 Jul 2015. I wish I lived nearer to this place, they do a cooked vegan breakfast at 70p an item (apart from toast which is still a reasonable £1 for 2 slices). Items included fried mushrooms, baked beans, hash browns, sausages, bacon and tofu scramble. My dad is not veg*n but still really enjoyed this, and I was very pleased to be able to opt for a vegan pain au chocolat, not a choice I think I've ever seen in a commercial establishment before and an extremely welcome one! I was also impressed with the amount of useful groceries they had for sale, including Hodmedod dried beans and quinoa, vegan marshmallows, Vego bars, Suma vital wheat gluten, and many more, dotted around on a few different shelves! We also liked the shelves full of games and puzzles provided for customers, and the big jug of water which was brought over after we asked for a glass of tap water. The proprietor was really friendly too, and kindly wrote down a cake recipe for my mum. The only improvement I would suggest is that I think there should be more indication that items are vegan (even if it's just a V by each item, as that's usually a code we understand!), I almost didn't think to ask if the pain au chocolat were vegan, I found out because I asked if there were any vegan cakes and were told they all are, and it was only later on that I saw a blackboard stating that everything is plant-based apart from dairy milk for drinks. 
Pros: Friendly and helpful, inexpensive, tasty food 
Cons: labelling could be clearer, location a bit out of the way

thread.title: Picazzo's Organic Italian Kitchen - Sedona Arizona Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Picazzo's Organic Italian Kitchen - Sedona Arizona Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Picazzo's Organic Italian Kitchen - Sedona Arizona Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
keep your expectations low - Edit Posted by jenly on 18 Apr 2017. I am always eternally grateful to Happy Cow when we are travelling, so I feel compelled to leave reviews after visiting restaurants I learned about on this site. Picazzo is an upscale, airy pizza restaurant with a full bar and fairly extensive menu. Yes, they have Beyond Meat chickn strips but the kitchen overall needs a culinary upgrade. We ordered the Zoe salad which came with the chikn but I don't think it had been cooked well before adding it to the salad since it had that hard texture it gets right from the package. Otherwise the salad was nice and family enjoyed it. Other items we ordered included a Daiya pizza with vegan crust and a couple of toppings, a regular cheese pizza, some kind of alfredo noodle dish with the Beyond Meat, and the zucchini noodle dish with the cauliflower sauce. The item was the vegan pizza with the gluten free crust and spicy sauce.. The dairy pizza was completely tasteless and the pasta dishes also flavorless and not enjoyed by the kids. I found the zucchini noodle dish to be a gloppy mess and overwhelmingly garlicky. A woman at the table next to us had ordered the same thing and sent her order back. There were a lot of good intentions here but execution was lacking. We went for lunch and it was pretty expensive for the five of us, so it would have been nice if the meal had been better. Chickn strips can only do so much by themselves. 
Pros: gluten free options, beyond meat chickn strips, extensive menu 
Cons: nothing was great, some items are just not good, pricy

It's not the cheapest that ALDI offers, but when you go to a vegan restaurant, you always expect this something little extra :) Prices are great and portions very good.

thread.title_full: Sen Yai Sen Lek - Minneapolis Minnesota Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Sen Yai Sen Lek - Minneapolis Minnesota Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text: My new favorite - Edit Posted by knejedly on 17 May 2012. First, thank you Happy Cow for helping me to find a vegan friendly restaurant, and what a wonderful find this was! The place appears very fun, funky and clean. The service was excellent, everyone was attentive and the food was AMAZING! They have a separate menu for vegetarian and vegan options and you do have to compare it to the main menu for the dish descriptions. The dishes are reasonbly priced and our selections were colorful, appealing and very flavorful. I have found my new favorite restaurant! I love the NE location ~ no traveling to downtown or uptown during rush hour. I would give this a five cow rating except that the highest one available for a non-vegetarian restaurant is four, which I cant' really argue in principle.

thread.title_full: Sister Srey Cafe - Siem Reap Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Sister Srey Cafe - Siem Reap Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
meh - Edit Posted by rburrke on 19 Jul 2017. The vibe was cool and I love what they do for charity. I want to like this place but honestly the food was meh and overpriced for portion and flavour. Each dish was about 4-6$ I got the falafel bowl and was pretty disappointed. Id say it was mostly filler as it was about 80% just plain brown rice. It came with 2 (small) falafel patties which were good, hummus and plain yogurt... pretty much it. There was no variety in flavors or textures, it was all just was kinda soft and mushy. My partner got the chili stir fry. Again, not bad but really nothing special. Tasted like generic sweet chili sauce and standard vegetables. Small portion and no tofu or beans or anything of the sort. We were hoping that a place offering specifically vegan dishes would atlease know the struggle of veg life in asia and provide SOME variety. Honestly, could have gotten something similar on the streets for 1$. 
Pros: cool atmosphere

thread.title: Green Vegetarian Cuisine - Downtown - San Antonio Texas Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Green Vegetarian Cuisine - Downtown - San Antonio Texas Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Green Vegetarian Cuisine - Downtown - San Antonio Texas Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Hit or miss, but mostly delicious - Edit Posted by saveur on 27 Jan 2014. I really enjoyed my meal here. Cheap, plentiful and delicious. I had the beet down juice which was very flavourful but the garlic was a bit zingy for my liking. I had the raw collard wrap which was nice although fell apart easily. I sampled my friends' dishes which were great (more flavourful than mine). They really do the sauces very well! The sesame chicken (seitan) was well flavoured, the chopped BBQ quesadilla (not vegan) had a strong BBQ flavour within the sauce but was nice and crisp. The special of the day was crispy asian eggplant with a delicious sauce over rice and steamed broccoli. The kale salad (side) was delicious. Simple but very flavourful. The refried beans were more like baked beans and were ok. My friends thought the vegan cupcakes were very good but I didn't try them. I wish I was staying longer so I could go back. I ended up taking half my collard wrap home as leftovers. Edited to add: The food can be a bit hit-or-miss. I came back a second day and the kale salad was so spicy I had to return it. The macrobiotic plate was great though, which I took home mostly as leftovers since it was so huge. The raw sushi was a bit lacklustre. Visited March 2011 
Pros: wide variety of options 
Cons: lack of consistency

Can't compain about the food as it was freshly prepared and prices are reasonable keeping in mind that it is pretty much in city center, a short walk from the central station. I guess the owner is by herself managing everything and her German skills are just adequate to place the order. I asked if she can suggest me a dish with Seitan and Thai curry, she insisted to select something from the menu. If you are in city and wanting to have good asian food, then visit this place.

thread.title: Veggie Bob's Kitchen - Fort Langley British Columbia Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Veggie Bob's Kitchen - Fort Langley British Columbia Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Veggie Bob's Kitchen - Fort Langley British Columbia Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Posted by purplethumb on 09 Jun 2016. Someone to come around and ask you if your meal is good if you have everything you need for us Bob was a one man show. No ice in your water and if it's chilly bring a jacket because Bob has a decidedly fresh air approach and the wind whistles through the premise. The decor is undecided except for "more is better" and when in doubt....add more!! Know the rules....get your own drink, chips if it applies and whatever else is on your menu selection. All that said and done Bob will make you THE BEST Veg/Vegan food you have EVER had bar none!! The sausage is to die for, the texture just like the best sausage anywhere (but tastes better). You might look for Bob if you want dessert....we were stuffed....or when you wish to pay but you will never forget the food!! Bob has some of the best flavor profiles anywhere! Thanks Bob for a wonderful meal we'll be back when it's warmer to sample more of your wares and hmmm maybe talk about the music? 
Pros: extraordinary flavour profiles, huge portions (and you just keep eating!), fair pricing....very good value! 
Cons: attention to detail (ex..customers), music too loud, heavy handed with the mustard!!

thread.title_full: Lov'n It Live - East Point Georgia Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Lov'n It Live - East Point Georgia Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
The Wait From Hell Fades When The Food Arrives - Edit Posted by VeganSnobATL on 21 May 2015. Slow, slow, slow your boat gently down the stream. Merrily, merrily, merrily the wait is hella extreme! We waited so long that the seasons changed. The service is so slow that I literally forgot what I had ordered. Here's the truth about Lovin' It Live. The wait is aweful. The service is unengaging and nonchalant. But the food will set you right! The food is consistly good. Been going for years and never had a bad meal so I keep going back. Now make sure you got a good job or your own business balling and even with that take your nitro-glycerine because the prices will give you a heart attack. It's definitely uptown compared to Tassili's (yuck). At Lovin' It Live after you grow accustomed to the "process" it's kinda like the soup nazi on Seinfeld. You go in, you don't make eye contact after you order and you graciously wait. Once your food arrives, you are happy as heck. The place is intimate and has a great vibe and nice art pieces. Again, understand the rules of engagement and the food will definitely shine. 
Pros: Good vibe, Excellent Raw Experience, Fresh and Organic 
Cons: You Could Install A Transmission Faster, Calling Ahead Is Like You Never Called, Not For the Snap Benefits Crowd

thread.title: El Punto Vegano - San Juan Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: El Punto Vegano - San Juan Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: El Punto Vegano - San Juan Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Do not miss! - Edit Posted by xmrfigx on 15 Feb 2017. Finally made it here! There are not many reviews online for this place but the ones that are there are well deserved 5s! After strolling along the main stretch in Condado, we decided to make the stop here for dinner. We met Ernesto who puts the menu together who recommended the burger and taco for us. ( The lunch buffet was already over) We ordered his suggestions and added a quesadilla to share. This food was so flavorful. The tortillas, if I understood properly are made from a gluten free cassava flour and added to the flavor of the taco and quesadilla. Ernesto kept checking in on us to make sure everything was good and he let me sample some of the macaroni salad he had left over from the lunch buffet. AMAZING! We took some to go to bring back to our hotel. He explained that the buffet normal starts when they open at 11. He decides on the menu every morning so it is different pretty much everyday. The buffet goes until around 3-4 when most things run out. He then has the standard menu which includes the food we ordered, plus a few additional items that can be put together quickly. This place is a definitely a must try for the service and flavor. 
Pros: Great, friendly service, Excellent local flavors, Nice selection 
Cons: Parking, Area is a little sketchy, go during the day

thread.title: Native Foods - Wicker Park - Chicago Illinois Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Native Foods - Wicker Park - Chicago Illinois Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Native Foods - Wicker Park - Chicago Illinois Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text: GREAT addition to Chicago!!! - Edit Posted by SynthVegan on 08 Aug 2011. Native Foods Cafe has been one of my favorite restaurants to visit while in California for quite some time now. Luckily for us Chicagoans, we can now stuff ourselves silly with as much NF's as we'd like - I'll have to step up my workout routine, but it's totally worth it! I was delighted to meet the mastermind behind all of the super-tasty menu items, Chef Tanya, she was very delightful, fun, and clearly passionate about what she does. All of the other employees were super nice too, as well as the manager, whom I had previously met in Tustin, CA. We ordered a few appetizers, entrees, desserts, and drinks - in sum the food was AMAZING. Appetizers: Native Nachos (chips, black beans, veg taco meat, chipotle crema, veg cheese, salsa, guacamole) - this was a tasty dish, although it wasn't my favorite. I really enjoyed the veg meat but didn't care for the cheese flavored drops that resembled fancy butter. Native Chicken Wings (crispy battered "chicken" wings served with ranch) - this dish was very tasty, even my non-vegan friends loved it. The ranch dressing that came with it is the best in the city! Entrees: Oklahoma Bacon Cheeseburger (seitan, daiya cheese, "bacon", caramelized onions, BBQ sauce, ranch dressing, and battered dill pickle chips) - this is, and always has been, my favorite dish! It's perfect for when you're craving a burger and fries, or just when you'd like to treat yourself to a good meal. This time I decided to be on the healthier side and ordered potato salad as my side, it was good and had a lot of dill in it, although I prefer the mayonnaise (vegenaise) based potato salads - I'll likely stick with fries next time. Chicken Run Ranch Burger (crispy battered "chicken", ranch dressing, lettuce, carrots, and onions) - my bf got this so I tried several bites. We both agreed that it wasn't much different from the chicken wings appetizer, so get one or the other, but not both at the same time. Rockin' Morracan Bowl ("chicken", veggies, quinoa) - my friend let me try this and I didn't care for it at all, however, he really enjoyed it...to each his/her own. Desserts: Cheesecake (served with blueberries) - I liked this NF's version better than others. Although you can taste the tofu flavor, it's very tasty! Strawberry Parfait - I loved this dessert! It was shockingly good. Chocolate Love Pie - this was good, but it had a carob flavor, and I'm not a huge fan of carob so I prefer the cheesecake, parfaits, and cupcakes to this.

thread.title: Veggies On Fire - The Hague - The Veggie Blog
thread.title_full: Veggies On Fire - The Hague - The Veggie Blog

posts.title: Veggies On Fire - The Hague - The Veggie Blog
posts.text:
Dining / Restaurants / Reviews Veggies On Fire – The Hague 
The Hague is one of my favorite cities in the Netherlands. The Hague is the city of peace and law, located on the coast of the North Sea with wide sandy beaches. It is a city of new styles and old masters, with shops, palaces, green parks and beautiful museums like the Mauritshuis. And above all, it is a city where you can eat great vegan food. 
John and Carin Galstaun run Veggies on Fire . They offer purely vegetable dishes and beverages. All ingredients they use are, whenever possible, of biological origin and locally grown. To give a dish a little kick they use some exotic products here and there. For example, their Chipotle Burger contains smoked chipotle peppers imported from Mexico. Chipotle Burger 
They state on their website: “By eating vegetables, you contribute to the environment, your health, and enhance animal welfare. There is a better economical use of water and other natural resources, and the choice of pure plant nutrition eventually leads to a much more efficient global food distribution. We will bring you good food and harmony in the broadest sense of the word, in our restaurant on the Beeklaan 385 in The Hague.” 
So, of course we had to check this restaurant out on our city trip to The Hague. Veggies on Fire is a great little restaurant. We made reservations and got a lovely table at the window. The restaurant was completely full. It was nice to see all the people enjoying their food. We liked that the chef came out of the kitchen to serve our dishes and that she gave us an explanation of the food. 
I had the Chipotle Burger. A spicy seasoned burger made of three kinds of beans, oats, rice and smoked Mexican peppers. It is served on a homemade bun with salad and potatoes from the oven. For me the burger could have been a bit less spicy but it was a surprisingly good dish. I especially loved the oven-baked potatoes. While eating we suddenly realized why the restaurant is called “Veggies on Fire”…because that is exactly what the dishes on the menu are…very spicy and hot! 
Whenever you are in The Hague, check this place out. You will be pleasantly surprised…and on fire! 

About the author: Mariëlle van de Kerkhof — happy urban gardener who loves to travel and eat great vegan food! www.mariellevandekerkhof.com 

Panna Cotta and front restaurant images courtesy of Veggies On Fire Facebook page . Comment via Facebook

thread.title_full: The Green Spot - Barcelona Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: The Green Spot - Barcelona Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Just the spot - Edit Posted by deadpledge on 17 May 2017. As many have already commented the decor inside the Green Spot is simply stunning, modern and chic but not in a pretentious way. Depending on where you are seated you can also see the marina. The staff are very attentive and friendly too putting you at ease straight away and most importantly the food is great. We went for lunch and ordered the yellow spot curry with black rice (€14.75) and the Sun choy bao tofu setas (€10.50), both of which were presented beautifully and tasted even better with a great depth of flavour. Some may say these prices are expensive but we thought it was value for money and will definitely return again. We also got a raspberry lemonade and apple press juice (€3.25) to wash it down, very refreshing indeed. If I did have one con, I would personally like to see a few more vegan options. In summary, Green Spot is a must to go to when you visit Barcelona but I would advise booking. 
Pros: Excellent tasty food, Great decor, Friendly staff 
Cons: Few more vegan options would be nice

thread.title_full: Maoz Falafel - Barcelona Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Maoz Falafel - Barcelona Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Cheap and convenient - Edit Posted by deadpledge on 19 Dec 2016. We visited here twice during our recent stay mainly out of convenience as it is open till late. On offer you can get a meal deal consisting of falafel, chips and a drink for about €12 or just buy a falafel individually for about €5. We decided to just get a falafel with one white pita and one wholemeal pita, which was tasty but nothing special. However, you can use the salad bar to refill as many times as you want, which was great with some good salad selections available. Unfortunately the shop can be very congested when busy and with limited seating available this can be very frustrating and time consuming. On the second occasion we visited I was extremely disappointed with one particular instance I witnessed where a staff member actually brought a selection of open meat sandwiches into the shop to eat whilst on their break. I'm not saying you have to be vegan to work at vegan outlets but at least show some respect. I just hope they washed their hands thoroughly. I doubt we will return next time around. 
Pros: Cheap, Refils available, Convenience 
Cons: Busy , Limited seating, Staff could be more respectful

posts.text:
Oddly amazing - Edit Posted by corinal on 01 Jun 2014. It a sportsbar-ish fastfood restaurant in very small town, which is why it was so surprising to walk in and find a large vegan menu on the board behind the counter and on the menus! We had the enchiladas suiza, which were excellent - I really enjoyed the beans and rice that went with it and the suiza sauce was good. It came with a little side salad similar to pico de gallo and that was nice too. Free chips and salsa with a salsa bar - I always love that. The chips were good, but the salsa not so much, though I only tried two of them (aguacate and fresh salsa). We also had a chimichanga because I miss them so much, but it was a bit greasy so we probably should have just ordered the burrito, which was the same thing, but not deep fried. Large portions, good service, fun atmosphere, and nice and shaded and cool as a refuge from the hot sun after a long drive. 
Pros: Large vegan menu, Big portions, Friendly staff 
Cons: Salsa could be better, Chimichanga too oily

thread.title: Nama Artisan Raw Foods - West London Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Nama Artisan Raw Foods - West London Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Nama Artisan Raw Foods - West London Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Best raw vegan cakes in London! - Edit Posted by jon active on 27 Aug 2016. Nama is a bit posh, kind of place you might find the cast of the Notting Hill film in!! But the tea is only £2.50 (I say only! how London am I?) which given it comes in a pot and you can get two cups out of it compares well with other less snazzy joints! But lets cut to the chase. If you like cake, raw cake, refined sugar free cake then you must try this place out. I am a big fan of the raw cakes at Vantra, 222 and Redemption and the occasional ones you get at Black Cat but Nama has in my humble (expert!) opinion surpassed all these. The Cherry, coffee layer cake (special) I had last night was as good if not better than any raw cake I have had before. Sturdy in consistency, thick and creamy with multiple flavours and textures twas a sensory delight. The chocolate ganache cake my cake eating comrade chose was also superb if a little less sophisticated! Photo included of the special layer cake. Staff were friendly and helpful too! It ain't cheap but its worth it. Next time I'll try the tiramisu! Updated from previous review on 2016-08-27 
Pros: Wonderful raw cake selection, friendly, just up the road from the Rough Trade shop 
Cons: Notting Hill!, Not cheap

posts.title: Vegans Cafe and Restaurant - Kyoto Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Eat like a king, ahem, I mean an Emperor - Edit Posted by Tamy on 24 Jul 2017. After a visit to the beautiful Fushimi Inari Shrine, there is not better place to grab a bite, or to stuff yourself with delicious food than this adorable little nook. The cafe lies about 15min away by foot from the shrine and it is well worth the walk, even in the sweltering summer heat. It's not hard to find, but it is a bit camouflaged into the corner, so look left if you're coming from the shrine and turn the corner. The cafe has a varied menu consisting of a number of interesting dishes such as casseroles, curry, pizza, etc. Following the suggestion of other reviews, we tried their miso ramen and asked for it not to be spicy. The dish came in a heaping, steaming bowl that was a challenge to finish. We were stuffed by the end of it, but it was so delicious we dared not leave a single spoonful. The ramen came with plenty of noodles as well as soy sprouts and various almost raw vegetables (not soggy) in a delicious miso broth. By far the best vegan ramen we have ever had. We also tried their soft serve ice cream and tiramisu. The ice cream was delicious with a sweet, yet mild, vanilla type tofuish flavor. It had true soft serve ice cream texture and came bathed in a sauce of our choosing, The tiramisu was truthfully disappointing, as it did not taste at all like coffee but rather a bit sour. Not very pleasant. Overall we greatly enjoyed our meal at Vegans Cafe and Restaurant and would undoubtedly return in the future for a delicious bowl of ramen followed by some creamy soy soft serve. 
Pros: generous portions, friendly staff, delicious food 
Cons: pricey, distant, very little English spoken

Hands down. The people are super nice and the food is just out of this world. It's inexpensive and the portions are more than enough. Being new to "raw" and not very familiar with the menu there, Arga, the person who cooks everything offered me and my girlfriend samples of most of what was in the raw food case/cooler and right away I knew we were in the right place. We were a little put off because of the location being pretty far from where we normally travel for food, but once we tried the salads, now we're hooked! Arga even gives raw food preparation classes so you can make many of the same wonderful delicious from the comfort of your own home if you so desire. I'm a bit hesitant to put such a glowing review here because I'm afraid that too many people will discover how wonderful it is and this once hidden treasure among the raw food community will begin to be so busy I can't get a table. They have a revolving menu of daily specials so you can always expect something new to tempt you. 
Pros: Excellent Raw Food, Friendly Atmosphere, Nice Portions 
Cons: Location (A Little Far)

thread.title: Falafel Banin Johnny - Tel Aviv Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Falafel Banin Johnny - Tel Aviv Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Falafel Banin Johnny - Tel Aviv Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Smooth/Delicious Falafel - Edit Posted by A.Z.P. on 19 Jun 2017. What Israeli Falafel and American Bagels share in common, is that they should be crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Falafel banin is exactly that! The Falafels here are little yellow balls (which you could eat like popcorn) that are really fresh, with a flavor and texture inside which is much smoother than the more commonly found green falafel balls, Johnny, the owner (and the son of the original owners), is also a character who takes tremendous pride in his product. The first time I went in, I tried ordering without french fries and he strongly persuaded me to include them. Wow, was he right!!! These are no common instant fries, they are fresh potatoes fried up deliciously and one of the best parts of the meal. This is a place with a steady stream of regular customers where you'll find the common folk of Israel, There's a reason this place has been a Tel Aviv Falafel institution for over 60 years, and hopefully it will be for another 60, as we say in Israel, Ad 120 (at least!) Updated from previous review on 2017-06-19 
Pros: Great flavors, Great authentic local experience, Kosher

thread.title: Gracias Madre - WeHo - West Hollywood California Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Gracias Madre - WeHo - West Hollywood California Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Gracias Madre - WeHo - West Hollywood California Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text: Great vegetarian restaurant with outside seating - Edit Posted by jackie.r.7289 on 24 May 2016. Gracias Madre is one of our favorite restaurants in San Francisco and Los Angeles! While the whole menu is vegan, it's one of those places you could take a carnivore or a vegan too, because the options are varied and the cashew cheese is phenomenal, so you don't simply feel you're eating a plate of vegetables. We took a friend whose from Mexico City to the San Francisco location, and he requested to go back again when he came back to town with his wife (both are meat eaters) - to me, that's a true testament to this place! However, in comparison to the San Francisco location (quite dark and a bit awkwardly shaped with many communal tables), this location is one of the most gorgeous restaurants I've ever seen! The inside is quite large and there's a good amount of space between tables. The outside area may even be a bit larger, and it again looks like something out of a design magazine. No touch was forgotten about, and you immediately feel comfortable in this place. Service is generally good here too, and the clientele is more of a Hollywood vibe and less of a hipster vibe, which the SF location is more of. Cocktails are strong and creatively designed. They have a variety of drinks (and a mocktail or two) on the menu. Note that they are expensively priced for what you're getting though. Especially with the mocktail - it ends up being a lot of ice for what you pay for! The appetizers and mains are fantastic here! Guacamole is good, anything with cashew cheese on it is creamy and filling and the entrees come with a sizable amount of food. Our favorite dish is the tamal mojado - a very satisfying dish that comes with pickled vegetables and rice. The sauce is thick and spicy, without being overwhelmingly so. Their coconut bacon is also very cool. It doesn't try to impersonate bacon, and instead has an almost bacon-like texture with great coconut flavor, very unique! The only course that sometimes leaves something to be desired is dessert. We've tried cheesecake, their gluten-free black bean brownie and their chocolate cake. I found all to not be quite as deliciously sweet as a non-vegan dessert (we've even had better vegan versions of all three elsewhere). The black bean brownie came with sauces drizzled on top which certainly made it sweet, but not in the best kind of way. I recommend going elsewhere for dessert. Overall, a very solid restaurant - it could be a perfect date spot or a great place to bring the whole family due to its size!

thread.title: Veggielicious Cafe - Penang Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Veggielicious Cafe - Penang Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Veggielicious Cafe - Penang Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
If vegan, stay clear - Edit Posted by samlowry on 15 Jan 2017. I do not like complaining about food or people or places. But. To spare someone from the same mistake - if you eat vegan, go to the nearby vegan Sushi cafe instead. This place is at the end of a hotel lobby. Was the only customer. Waited quite a while before I got someone's attention. Then, whilst being pressured to ordering (had barely had a chance to look at the menu) I asked what was vegan to smooth the social awkwardness. They said they can make the mushroom-o-something burger vegan. :) So far nice. I asked how. "We remove the cheese and the mayo." "And what's left then? Is there any salad to go with it?" "There is lettuce and pepper sauce." "Well, ok. Let's try. One burger please then". What arrived gets A for the effort to bring a decent Quorn type of burger to Gerogetown, and and F for everything else. :) What appeared was two honest thick slices of fungi-burger between a bun. And a mini-tad of lettuce. And. The top of the burger was literally cold. I pointed that out, it was taken to the kitchen, and I heard a bell. I suspect it was a microwave. "Did you also microwave the salad now?" "No, we heated the burger up." "Ok...". "I'm sorry, I will not eat this, but since I ordered it, I'm happy to pay." (I was hoping for a return politeness, which did not compute). So I paid, to support a vegetarian place in their efforts, and to not be arrogant, and asked for the thing for takeway. I tasted it on my way to the vegan Sushi place nearby - the bread had deflated (indicating potential microwaving of the fluffy bread). The flavoring of the sauces was nice, but what was left is very nearly not food :). I suppose if one is a lacto-ovo vegetarian, it goes smoother there. I visited a number of Georgetown's vegan and vegetarian places and this one I would not go back there. Updated from previous review on 2017-01-15 
Pros: Idea; Desire to also offer a vegan option (no , Effort of bringing rare things to to Penang, Enthusiasm, caring about animals 
Cons: Pseudo-vegan vegan food (dish minus things=vegan), Unfortunate location, setup and ambience, Service - a simple no would have been better :) 
A top-cold burger :) 
Bread, meat analogue and a couple of pieces of let... 
The saddest vegan burger in the world calling for ...

thread.title: Moment - Prague Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Moment - Prague Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Moment - Prague Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
The seitan bagel!!! - Edit Posted by don.banano on 29 Jul 2017. Oh boy oh boy... Little did I know about what to expect as I was approaching this little cosy bistro in a nice area a little outside of the city centre. I had heard about the place from a friend and went there expecting a nice little snack before my flight back home. They have super cheap daily menus and I was considering ordering the soup+lasagne set, but then I remembered that no matter what I should go for the seitan bagel. And I was not disappointed! It was really HUGE, filled with deliciously marinated seitan and various veggies, including one of my all time favourites: pickled cucumber. And it tasted like heaven. A few fresh french fries with a bit of some kind of a spicy sauce were on the side and a nice simple salad. I really did not expect too be that blown away but I was! I am definitely going to recommend it to everybody who is going to go Prague. The only little minus is that they don't accept credit cards, but that can be easily improved :-) 
Pros: food, everything else

thread.title_full: Spicy Thai Restaurant - St Catharines Ontario Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Spicy Thai Restaurant - St Catharines Ontario Veg-options Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Sweet and Spicy, kinda Dicey - Edit Posted by pheonix on 31 Jan 2007. I went to Spicy Thai on a date with a non veg, a carnivore through and through. The building looks really interesting from the outside and it's hard to miss. Bright yellow paint on the outside with SPICY THAI painted in bold red. It's really nice inside. Some "traditional" areas to eat where you're sitting kind of on the ground. I didn't see much of this, we got a table, though I would have liked to eat there. Menus not bad, very diverse. Most things can be made vegan and you can tell them how spicey you like it. That's a bonus. WARNING: Mild is no spice, medium is REALLY hot. The staff was super friendly and well informed, so props to Spicy Thai on that one. The food was alright. I had Pad Thai, vegan of course. It was overly sweet and I couldn't eat much. There were these weird vegetables things in it. They looked really freaky and that turned me off. I hate admitting that because I'm usually over the top open minded about food. My date had some seafood meadley thing. Mussels, oeysters, shrimp and so on. He liked it alot. The prices weren't bad. We paid 30$ for both of us. I don't think I'll be going back because I got really bad diahrea the next day but for other people it's a nice place. 
Pros: Decor, Funky traditional areas, Great staff 
Cons: mysterious vegetables, hard to find entrance, diahrea

Fantastic food, healthy, hearty and delicious. I never realised vegetables could be so tasty and have eaten here almost every night since. The snack dishes are huge and yummy. I especially recommend the Gespacio and babaganoush with homemade flatbread. The mains are just as delicious, beautifully presented also and very filling. G put's a lot of attention into textures, flavours and it's a visual feast to boot and the prices are very reasonable for the quality and freshness. They make pretty much all of it in front of your eyes from scratch! I highly recommend whether you are visiting Siem Reap or a long term resident. Jokes aside tho, this place deserves 5 stars, because it is the best veg food i have eaten anywhere in the world. Simply delicious :)

posts.title: Lulu's Local Eatery - St Louis Missouri Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Dog city - Edit Posted by SkyFitzgerald on 20 Oct 2017. I visited with my girlfriend - a newly turned vegan - after a seven-hour drive to St. Louis from Indiana. We were so happy to finally arrive that we sat outside in the fresh air, under the fairy lights and surrounded by dogs!! It was an added bonus. I got the loaded nachos and Lucy got the pesto mac and cheese with a side of tater tots. The portions were all pretty small in size but were all pretty filling!! The nachos were made with blue corn chips which were unique and an added twist. They also did birthday cake cups which is my favourite flavour of anything but we didn't get one to try because I was paying. It was pretty busy though, and they ran out of food quite quickly. 
Pros: good food, allows and encourages dogs! , pretty decoration 
Cons: busy and loud, ran out of pasta, lack of communication between staff 
Loaded nachos, pesto mac and cheese and tater tots...

thread.title: Zakaim - Vegan Boutique - Tel Aviv Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: Zakaim - Vegan Boutique - Tel Aviv Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: Zakaim - Vegan Boutique - Tel Aviv Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Not Consistent - Edit Posted by ShanaCohen on 22 Mar 2017. We have been here many times over the past few years and loved the place and the food, although always too oily and salty. The creativity with the food is wonderful. Yesterday we were there and all our breads and food was burnt which in itself it very unhealthy to eat black burnt food. The hostess was very rude saying this is how it is always cooked and they must burn the flat bread and put oil on everything. She was not listening to anything we said, such as we have been here many times before and never had burnt food. She was literally angry and upset with us for pointing out the burnt food. We didn't recognize the wait staff maybe they are new but the cooks were not and the food was all burnt. We have brought friends and groups here over the years to introduce them to vegan food, but we will not return again. This experience was so counter all the other and overall they just didn't care what we said, and I believe the staff was just not informed. When a place is consistent then there are none of these issues, so I dont know either they always burn the food and the past 20 times we have been there we got luck and it wasn't burnt, or this one time it is burnt is really the way they cook? Tel Aviv has so many options but I hope this place will educate their staff and cooks to stay consistent hopefully with not burning the food. If they go back to non burnt food it is very tasty but a meal only to eat once a month with how salty, rich and oily it is. If they keep burning the food then it is not worth it at all. As we paid a lot of money last night for burnt food and no understanding that this is not acceptable food to eat. 
Pros: ambiance, open kitchen

organizations.name: zakaim - vegan boutique - tel aviv vegan restaurant

thread.title: The Cherokee Rose Inn - Portland Oregon Hotel Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: The Cherokee Rose Inn - Portland Oregon Hotel Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: The Cherokee Rose Inn - Portland Oregon Hotel Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Great stay with Sandy at The Cherokee Rose Inn - Edit Posted by Santerra on 07 Apr 2014. Such a great place to stay! I've never stayed at a B&B before and wasn't originally planning to for my trip, but this little gem popped up on HappyCow and my boyfriend and I decided to try something new and let me tell you...It did not disappoint. The location is just on the other side of the river from downtown and conveniently located within walking distance to many restaurants, bars and boutiques. For the vegans out there, it is minutes away from the vegan strip mall and a great vegan bar called The Sweet Hereafter. Sandy is beyond sweet and she goes above and beyond to make sure your stay is comfortable and unobtrusive (although, ironically, I wished that she would be more intrusive because I love talking to people and hearing their stories. But that's just my personality). The room and the bathroom were huge and we were met with complimentary vegan truffles. The bed was so comfortable and in the morning Sandy had a delicious, vegan, southwest breakfast ready for us (I ate 3 biscuits and would've eaten more if others hadn't wanted the rest). And lastly...her lovely pets. She has the sweetest little dog that looks like the dog from the Caesar food commercials and the absolute sweetest cat named Bill who knows tricks. I highly recommend Sandy and a stay at her B&B. Not only will I be staying there for all trips to Portland, but the stay has also convinced me to explore other B&B's on other vacations. This place is great for vegans because of the guaranteed vegan breakfast, but even if you're not vegan, it's great because the food is amazing and the stay is relaxing. 
Pros: Vegan, Location, Sandy

thread.title: WTF - What Tasty Food - Kuala Lumpur Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: WTF - What Tasty Food - Kuala Lumpur Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: WTF - What Tasty Food - Kuala Lumpur Vegetarian Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Indian restaurant with some Western &vegan options - Edit Posted by AndyT on 29 May 2014. If your motto in life is "CHEEESE!!! I must at least eat half a kilo of it every day " ... Then WTF might be just the right place for you. If you are vegan, however, or if you simply like to eat healthy food, then possibly not. When I read the description, I got the impression that it is a restaurant with main,y Western style food. That is not the case. About 90 % of their menu is Indian, and they do have a few Western options. Burger, Pizza, cheese sandwich and some Mexican food. The common deniminator is that they are laden with either cheese, butter or ghee, reflecting the school of thought that is - unfortunataly - also often encountered in Vegetarian restaurants, that mankind can not survive without animal products :-( However, their prices are much too high for average Indian food. Aloo mutter for RM 10 is ok, charging RM 2 for each single piece of chapatti on top of that, and RM 2 for a jug of ice water is rather steep, but asking RM 7 for a glass of Lemon Iced tea and RM 9 for a small mango lassi are too expensive IMO. I went there with my non-vegan son, he ate one of the mini-pizzas (the second one was too much for him), I helped him with his fries and had the Aloo Mutter with some Chapattis. The lemon ice tea that I ordered without sugar was very sweet, so when I ordered another one, I specifically asked that no sugar at all be added. The drink I received tasted similar to normal Lipton's out of the can and the "normal" lemon ice tea that my son had ordered would probably have sent a diabetic person into a coma after the first sip. After the lunch, both my son and myself had indigestion, something that I, as a vegan, am simply not used to. The redeeming factor of WTF is the friendliness of their personnel. The waiter explained which of their options were vegan, and when my son ordered a Mango lassi, he came back to check if that was really ok, as I had asked specifically for no dairy in the food (and lassi is made of yoghurt). Nevertheless, with only average food and above average prices, this is clearly not sufficient for a better rating. 
Pros: Friendly staff, Taste ok 
Cons: Prices very high for what they offer, Few vegan options, Food definitely not healthy

organizations.name: tasty food - kuala lumpur vegetarian restaurant - happycow indian

thread.title: 20000 Cows Vegetarian House - Lismore Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
thread.title_full: 20000 Cows Vegetarian House - Lismore Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow

posts.title: 20000 Cows Vegetarian House - Lismore Vegan Restaurant - HappyCow
posts.text:
Not worth your time or money - Edit Posted by vegan mikal on 21 Jul 2012. 20,000 Cows may be an institution, but it's time is well past. Having been to 20,000 Cows more than a decade earlier and having enjoyed that experience, we were looking forward to the new owner reopening the place. Our anticipation did not match the reality. If you feel like dining in someone's crumbling loungeroom, then this is the place for you. The lack of care of the premises is just the start. We were so shocked by the prices (which didn't have a hint of being "suggestions" in any way) that we decided to try some of the cheaper options; a curry for $25 in Australia in 2012 is found in places with gold cutlery, not with a bunch of cobwebs! Our entree of spinach and nut cheese rolls consisted of two pencil-thin tubes of pastry containing a leaf of spinach and something white. Whether this white stuff was made out of nuts was impossible to say. This was truly a minimalist item both on size and on taste. Our main was a pasta with a coconut milk and mushroom sauce. This was a bland and hastily prepared meal, with a strange mix of cooked and uncooked vegetables. It was at least 1/3 too expensive. Thankfully there was a nice paratha to finish off our meal, but it too was small for the price. We decided to cut our losses and did not order any of the overpriced desserts. There is very little going for this place. The waitresses seemed unsure of what they were doing, we never got the water we were offered, and even the bill was mucked up. The new owner took over only in early 2012, but really, 20,000 Cows should have retired a long time ago. It needs a lot of work to get up to scratch. 
Pros: none
